poem:
Gaelic Dawn

In Galway's mist, Connolly rises,  
a beacon of ancient words  
renewed. Humbled tongues,  
once whispered in shadows,  
now dance in daylight,  
unfurled flags in breeze.  
Kneecap's beats,  
a quiet girl's gaze,  
echo through halls.  
Ireland's heart pulses  
in vibrant Gaelic breath—  
a language reborn,  
to sing once more.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Hopes of Irish language revival in public life as Catherine Connolly takes office The Irish language has scored cultural breakthroughs with the film The Quiet Girl and the controversial rap trio Kneecap and is now about to acquire a new talisman: Catherine Connolly. When the independent leftwing politician is inaugurated as Ireland’s president on Tuesday, she will carry hopes of a transformational Gaelic revival. The former barrister from Galway made Gaelic a central part of". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
